In Julia, Write a pig latin transformer called `pig_latinify` that operates on a vector of strings. It iterates over each string and changes it to pig latin. Each iteration should run on a separate thread.

To write a pig latin transformer called `pig_latinify` in Julia that operates on a vector of strings using separate threads, we can use the `Threads` module in Julia for parallel processing. Here's how you can implement it:

```julia
using Threads

function pig_latinify(str::String)
    first_letter = str[1]
    consonants = ["b", "c", "d", "f", "g", "h", "j", "k", "l", "m", "n", "p", "q", "r", "s", "t", "v", "w", "x", "y", "z"]
    vowels = ["a", "e", "i", "o", "u"]

    if isempty(str) || isfirstletter(vowels, first_letter)
        return str
    end

    position = findfirst(x -> x == first_letter, consonants)
    new_str = string(str[position:end], string(str[1:position-1], "ay"))
    return new_str
end

function pig_latin_transform!(strs::Vector{String})
    Threads.@threads for str in strs
        str[1] = pig_latinify(str[1])
    end
end

function main()
    strs = ["apple", "banana", "cherry", "dog", "elephant"]
    pig_latin_transform!(strs)
    println(strs)
end
```

In this example, `pig_latinify` function takes a single string as its argument and returns the pig latin version of it. The `pig_latin_transform!` function uses the `Threads.@threads` macro to apply the pig latin transformation concurrently on all strings in the given vector `strs`. The `main` function demonstrates how to use the `pig_latin_transform!` function.

Keep in mind that this example may not show significant performance improvement, as the strings are very short. In practice, you might want to apply this function to long strings or large datasets to achieve noticeable speedup.
